notes:
1. Concept

The First Law of Thermodynamics is a version of the law of conservation of energy, adapted for thermodynamic systems. It states that the change in the internal energy of a closed system is equal to the amount of heat supplied to the system, minus the amount of work done by the system on its surroundings.

2. Equation for a Closed System

The most common form of the First Law is:

$$ \Delta U = Q - W $$
  • $\Delta U$ is the change in the internal energy of the system.
  • $Q$ is the net heat transferred into the system.
  • $W$ is the net work done by the system.

3. Sign Conventions

The sign convention is critical:

  • Heat (Q):
    • $Q > 0$: Heat is added to the system.
    • $Q < 0$: Heat is removed from the system.
  • Work (W):
    • $W > 0$: Work is done by the system (e.g., expansion).
    • $W < 0$: Work is done on the system (e.g., compression).

solvedExamples.question: A closed system undergoes a process in which 100 J of heat is added to it, and the system does 40 J of work on its surroundings. What is the change in the internal energy of the system?
solvedExamples.explanation: Use the First Law of Thermodynamics: $\Delta U = Q - W$. Heat is added, so $Q = +100$ J. Work is done by the system, so $W = +40$ J. Therefore, $\Delta U = 100 - 40 = 60$ J.

solvedExamples.question: During a process, the internal energy of a system decreases by 200 J. If 50 J of work is done on the system, how much heat was transferred?
solvedExamples.explanation: We are given $\Delta U = -200$ J (decrease). Work is done on the system, so $W = -50$ J. Rearranging the First Law to solve for Q: $Q = \Delta U + W$. $Q = (-200) + (-50) = -250$ J. A negative value for Q means that 250 J of heat was removed from the system.
